questions.stem: An I/O psychologist is selecting employees for a high-stakes position and wants to maximize predictive validity while minimizing adverse impact. Which combination of selection methods would BEST achieve this goal based on meta-analytic research?
options: Unstructured interviews combined with graphology
General mental ability test combined with a structured interview
Personality test alone using the Big Five
Years of experience combined with unstructured interviews
questions.explanation: Meta-analytic research (Schmidt & Hunter, 1998) demonstrates that general mental ability (GMA) tests have the highest single predictor validity for job performance (.51). When combined with structured interviews (which add incremental validity of about .12), the combination achieves the highest overall predictive validity (.63). Structured interviews also have lower adverse impact than cognitive tests alone, partially offsetting the adverse impact of GMA tests. Unstructured interviews have much lower validity (.38) and graphology has near-zero validity. Personality tests alone have modest validity (.31 for conscientiousness), and years of experience has lower validity than GMA (.18).

questions.stem: According to Fiedler's Contingency Model of Leadership, a task-oriented leader would be MOST effective in which situation?
options: When situational favorability is moderate
When situational favorability is either very high or very low
When all subordinates have high need for achievement
When the leader has been in the position for more than five years
questions.explanation: Fiedler's Contingency Model proposes that leadership effectiveness depends on the match between leadership style (task-oriented vs. relationship-oriented, measured by the Least Preferred Coworker scale) and situational favorability (determined by leader-member relations, task structure, and position power). Task-oriented leaders are most effective in extreme situations—either very favorable (good relations, structured tasks, strong power) or very unfavorable (poor relations, unstructured tasks, weak power). Relationship-oriented leaders are most effective in moderately favorable situations. A key feature of Fiedler's model is that leadership style is considered relatively fixed, so the situation should be modified to fit the leader rather than vice versa.

questions.stem: Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory distinguishes between hygiene factors and motivators. Which of the following is a key implication of this theory for organizational management?
options: Improving salary and working conditions is the most effective way to increase intrinsic motivation
Eliminating dissatisfaction (through hygiene factors) does not automatically create satisfaction; motivators must also be present
Employees are equally motivated by all job characteristics regardless of individual differences
Job enrichment programs should focus exclusively on improving supervisory relationships
questions.explanation: Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory (Motivation-Hygiene Theory) proposes that satisfaction and dissatisfaction are not opposite ends of a single continuum but are influenced by different factors. Hygiene factors (salary, working conditions, supervision, company policies, job security) prevent dissatisfaction when adequate but do not create satisfaction or motivation. Motivators (achievement, recognition, the work itself, responsibility, advancement) create satisfaction and motivation when present. Thus, improving hygiene factors only moves employees from dissatisfied to not dissatisfied (neutral), while motivators are needed to move from neutral to satisfied/motivated. This is the theoretical basis for job enrichment interventions.

questions.stem: A job analyst uses the Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ) to analyze a set of jobs. Which characteristic BEST describes the PAQ as a job analysis method?
options: It is a worker-oriented method that analyzes jobs in terms of human behaviors and attributes required
It is a task-oriented method that produces detailed descriptions of specific job tasks
It is a competency-based method focused exclusively on managerial positions
It is a critical incident technique that identifies exemplary and poor performance behaviors
questions.explanation: The Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ), developed by McCormick, Jeanneret, and Mecham, is a structured, worker-oriented job analysis instrument. It analyzes jobs along 187 job elements organized into six divisions: information input, mental processes, work output, relationships with others, job context, and other job characteristics. Because it focuses on generalized human behaviors rather than specific tasks, it allows comparison across different jobs. This contrasts with task-oriented methods (which describe specific job duties), competency modeling (which focuses on KSAs for specific roles), and the critical incident technique (which collects behavioral examples of effective/ineffective performance).

questions.stem: According to Vroom's Expectancy Theory, an employee's motivation to perform is determined by the multiplicative combination of which three factors?
options: Need strength, equity perception, and goal difficulty
Expectancy (effort-to-performance), instrumentality (performance-to-outcome), and valence (value of outcome)
Self-efficacy, outcome expectations, and environmental supports
Existence needs, relatedness needs, and growth needs
questions.explanation: Vroom's Expectancy Theory (VIE Theory) proposes that motivation (force) equals Expectancy x Instrumentality x Valence. Expectancy is the belief that effort will lead to successful performance (effort-to-performance). Instrumentality is the belief that successful performance will lead to certain outcomes (performance-to-outcome). Valence is the value or attractiveness of those outcomes to the individual. Because the relationship is multiplicative, if any component is zero, overall motivation is zero. Option A mixes concepts from equity theory and goal-setting theory. Option C describes SCCT. Option D describes Alderfer's ERG theory.

questions.stem: Which of the following are identified as characteristics of transformational leadership according to Bass and Avolio's Full Range Leadership Model? (Select ALL that apply)
options: Idealized influence (charisma)—leader serves as a role model
Inspirational motivation—articulating a compelling vision
Intellectual stimulation—encouraging creative problem-solving
Management by exception—intervening only when problems arise
Individualized consideration—attending to each follower's development needs
questions.explanation: Bass and Avolio's Full Range Leadership Model identifies four components of transformational leadership (the '4 I's'): Idealized Influence—leaders earn trust and serve as role models; Inspirational Motivation—leaders communicate an appealing vision and express confidence; Intellectual Stimulation—leaders encourage followers to question assumptions and think creatively; Individualized Consideration—leaders act as mentors attending to individual needs. Management by exception (active or passive) is a component of transactional leadership, not transformational leadership. Transformational leadership consistently predicts higher follower satisfaction, motivation, and performance beyond transactional leadership.

questions.stem: According to meta-analytic research on employee selection methods, which of the following predictors have demonstrated substantial validity for predicting job performance? (Select ALL that apply)
options: General mental ability (GMA) tests
Work sample tests
Structured behavioral interviews
Graphology (handwriting analysis)
Conscientiousness measures
questions.explanation: Schmidt and Hunter's (1998) comprehensive meta-analysis established the validity hierarchy for selection predictors. General mental ability tests show the highest single-predictor validity (.51). Work sample tests also show high validity (.54) but can only be used for experienced applicants. Structured interviews, particularly behavioral interviews (based on past behavior), demonstrate solid validity (.51 for structured vs. .38 for unstructured). Conscientiousness is the strongest Big Five personality predictor of job performance (.31). Graphology (handwriting analysis) has been consistently shown to have near-zero validity (.02) and is not a valid selection tool despite its continued use in some countries.

questions.stem: Which of the following statements about Adams' Equity Theory are accurate? (Select ALL that apply)
options: Employees compare their input-to-outcome ratio with that of referent others
Perceived inequity creates a tension that motivates the individual to restore equity
Overpayment inequity always leads to increased performance
Methods of restoring equity include changing inputs, changing outcomes, or cognitively distorting the situation
Employees may choose to leave the organization when inequity is perceived as severe and unresolvable
questions.explanation: Adams' Equity Theory posits that employees assess fairness by comparing their own input/outcome ratio to that of comparison others (referent others). When a discrepancy is perceived, a state of tension (inequity distress) arises that motivates attempts to restore equity. Restoration methods include: altering inputs (working harder or less), altering outcomes (requesting a raise), cognitive distortion (reinterpreting the situation), changing the referent other, or leaving the field (quitting). Option C is incorrect because overpayment inequity does not always increase performance—research shows it may temporarily increase quantity but not necessarily quality, and people often cognitively distort the situation rather than change behavior.

questions.stem: Which of the following are key moderators of goal-setting effectiveness according to Locke and Latham's Goal-Setting Theory? (Select ALL that apply)
options: Goal commitment—the individual must be dedicated to achieving the goal
Task complexity—for complex tasks, specific difficult goals may impair performance without adequate strategies
Feedback—individuals need information about their progress toward the goal
Goal proximity—only distal goals motivate behavior; proximal goals are irrelevant
Self-efficacy—confidence in one's ability to attain the goal affects effort and persistence
questions.explanation: Locke and Latham's Goal-Setting Theory identifies several moderators of the goal-performance relationship: Goal commitment is essential—goals only work when people are committed to them. Task complexity moderates the effect: for simple tasks, specific difficult goals enhance performance directly, but for complex tasks, people may need strategies and learning goals rather than performance goals. Feedback is necessary for goal pursuit—without it, people cannot monitor progress. Self-efficacy influences goal choice, commitment, and persistence. Option D is incorrect—research shows both proximal (short-term) and distal (long-term) goals are important; proximal goals enhance motivation by providing immediate targets and facilitating self-efficacy.

questions.stem: An organization is implementing Lewin's three-stage model of organizational change. Which of the following steps are correctly matched to the appropriate stage? (Select ALL that apply)
options: Unfreezing: creating dissatisfaction with the status quo and readiness for change
Moving/Changing: implementing new processes, behaviors, and structures
Refreezing: stabilizing the new state through reinforcement and integration into culture
Unfreezing: immediately implementing all changes before resistance develops
Refreezing: reverting to the original state if any problems emerge
questions.explanation: Lewin's three-stage change model consists of: (1) Unfreezing—disrupting the current equilibrium by creating awareness of the need for change, reducing resistance, and building motivation (not rushing implementation, which is option D); (2) Moving/Changing—actually implementing the new behaviors, processes, and structures through participation, communication, and support; (3) Refreezing—stabilizing the change by integrating it into organizational culture, policies, and reward systems (not reverting, which is option E). Lewin recognized that without proper refreezing, organizations tend to drift back to their previous state. This model remains foundational despite criticisms that change is now more continuous than episodic.

questions.stem: Match each leadership theory to its primary proposition:

columns.text: Leaders form differential relationships with subordinates (in-group vs. out-group)
Leadership effectiveness depends on matching fixed style to situational favorability
Leaders should adapt style based on subordinates' readiness level
Leaders motivate by clarifying paths to goals and removing obstacles

questions.explanation: Fiedler's Contingency Model posits that leadership style (measured by LPC) is relatively fixed; effectiveness depends on matching style to situational favorability (leader-member relations, task structure, position power). Hersey-Blanchard's Situational Leadership proposes leaders should adapt their style (telling, selling, participating, delegating) based on followers' readiness (ability and willingness). House's Path-Goal Theory states leaders motivate by making paths to goals clear, removing obstacles, and providing appropriate support—the leader's style should match subordinate and environmental characteristics. LMX Theory focuses on the dyadic relationship quality between leader and each subordinate, differentiating between high-quality (in-group) and low-quality (out-group) exchanges.

questions.stem: Match each motivation theory to the theorist who developed it:
questions.explanation: Maslow proposed the Hierarchy of Needs with five levels (physiological, safety, belongingness, esteem, self-actualization) in a prepotency arrangement. Alderfer modified Maslow's hierarchy into three categories (Existence, Relatedness, Growth) in his ERG Theory, allowing for simultaneous pursuit and frustration-regression. McClelland's Acquired Needs Theory focuses on three learned needs (achievement, affiliation, power) and their influence on work motivation and leadership. Deci and Ryan's Self-Determination Theory distinguishes between intrinsic and extrinsic motivation, emphasizing three innate psychological needs: autonomy, competence, and relatedness.

questions.stem: For each organizational theory perspective, select ALL characteristics that apply:

columns.text: Emphasizes efficiency through task standardization and time-motion studies
Highlights the importance of social factors and worker attitudes
Views organizations as open systems interacting with their environment
Assumes workers are primarily motivated by economic incentives
Recognizes equifinality—multiple paths to the same outcome

questions.explanation: Classical/Scientific Management (Taylor, Fayol, Weber) emphasizes efficiency through task analysis, standardization, time-motion studies, and assumes economic motivation (workers as rational economic beings). The Human Relations movement, emerging from the Hawthorne Studies (Mayo, Roethlisberger), demonstrated that social factors, group norms, and worker attitudes significantly influence productivity—challenging the purely economic model. Systems Theory (Katz & Kahn, von Bertalanffy) views organizations as open systems with inputs, throughputs, outputs, and feedback loops interacting with the external environment, recognizing equifinality (multiple means to achieve the same end state) and the importance of adaptation.

questions.stem: For each performance appraisal method, select ALL common rating errors or biases it is particularly susceptible to:

columns.text: Reduced rater acceptance due to lack of transparency
High development cost but reduced ambiguity

questions.explanation: Graphic rating scales are the most common appraisal method but are susceptible to halo effect (rating all dimensions similarly based on overall impression), central tendency (clustering ratings around the midpoint), and leniency/severity (systematically rating too high or low). Forced-choice methods reduce these biases by requiring raters to choose between equally desirable descriptors, but suffer from low rater acceptance because raters cannot see how their responses translate to evaluations (lack of transparency). BARS (Behaviorally Anchored Rating Scales) use specific behavioral anchors at each scale point, reducing ambiguity and improving reliability, though they require substantial development effort (job-specific behavioral examples must be generated).

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about employee selection and validity:

The degree to which a selection test predicts future job performance is called [[1]] validity. When a test covers a representative sample of the content domain of the job, it demonstrates [[2]] validity. The selection approach that involves giving applicants a miniature replica of job tasks to perform is called a [[3]]. According to the Uniform Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures, if a selection procedure results in adverse impact (defined by the [[4]] rule), the employer must demonstrate the test's validity or find an alternative with less adverse impact.
questions.explanation: Criterion-related validity (specifically predictive validity) assesses how well test scores predict future job performance criteria. Content validity ensures the test representatively samples the job's content domain. Work sample tests require applicants to perform actual or simulated job tasks, providing high validity and face validity. The four-fifths (80%) rule from the Uniform Guidelines states that adverse impact exists when the selection rate for a protected group is less than 80% of the rate for the group with the highest rate. When adverse impact is present, employers must show evidence of validity.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about job satisfaction and its correlates:

The most widely used measure of overall job satisfaction is the [[1]]. Research has consistently shown that job satisfaction has a moderate negative correlation with [[2]] and a weaker but reliable relationship with job performance. The relationship between satisfaction and performance is best described by the [[3]] hypothesis, which suggests that rewards mediate the satisfaction-performance link. The facet of job satisfaction that tends to show the highest levels across workers is satisfaction with [[4]], while the facet with the lowest satisfaction tends to be satisfaction with [[5]].
questions.explanation: The Job Descriptive Index (JDI), developed by Smith, Kendall, and Hulin, is the most widely used and researched measure of job satisfaction, assessing five facets (work, pay, promotion, supervision, coworkers). Job satisfaction has a moderate negative correlation with turnover (r = -.25 to -.35)—dissatisfied employees are more likely to leave. The satisfaction-performance relationship (.30) is explained partly by the happy-productive worker hypothesis, which suggests rewards that satisfy employees also reinforce performance. Research consistently shows highest satisfaction with interpersonal relationships (coworkers, supervision) and lowest satisfaction with extrinsic rewards (pay, promotion opportunities).

questions.stem: An organization notices that employee turnover has increased by 40% over the past year, exit interviews reveal complaints about lack of recognition and limited growth opportunities, while salary benchmarking shows compensation is competitive with industry standards.
questions.centerStatement: Which motivational framework best explains the pattern of dissatisfaction despite competitive pay?

options.text: Hygiene factors (pay) are adequate but motivators (recognition, growth) are absent
Employees lack the ability to perform their jobs
Higher-order needs (esteem, self-actualization) are unmet despite lower needs being satisfied
All employees have identical motivational profiles
Implement job enrichment programs to increase autonomy and responsibility
Further increase salaries as the sole intervention
Create formal recognition programs and career development pathways
Provide mentoring and opportunities for professional growth

questions.explanation: Herzberg's Two-Factor Theory best explains this pattern: hygiene factors (competitive pay, adequate working conditions) prevent dissatisfaction but do not create satisfaction or motivation. The organization has addressed hygiene factors but neglected motivators (recognition, achievement, growth, responsibility). Simply increasing salary further (already adequate) would not address the core issue. Interventions must target motivator factors through job enrichment (increasing intrinsic task qualities), recognition programs, and career development. Maslow's hierarchy also applies: lower needs are met but esteem and self-actualization needs remain unfulfilled.

questions.stem: A manager notices that a high-performing team has recently experienced a significant drop in productivity. The decline began after the manager publicly praised and gave a substantial bonus to one team member while other equally contributing members received no recognition. Several team members have begun arriving late and reducing effort.
questions.centerStatement: Which theory best explains the decline in team productivity following the unequal reward distribution?

options.text: Team members perceive inequity in the input-to-outcome ratio
The rewarded employee's performance intimidated colleagues
Reduced effort is a method of restoring perceived equity
Team members lack the skills to perform at the previous level
Implement transparent, equitable reward distribution criteria
Ignore the situation and wait for it to resolve naturally
Acknowledge contributions of all team members who performed well
Ensure procedural and distributive justice in future reward decisions

questions.explanation: Adams' Equity Theory predicts that when employees perceive inequity (their input/outcome ratio differs from a referent other's), they experience distress and are motivated to restore equity. In this case, team members who contributed equally but received no reward perceive underpayment inequity compared to the rewarded colleague. Reducing effort (inputs) is a classic equity restoration strategy—by decreasing their inputs, they bring their ratio closer to balance. Solutions must address both distributive justice (fair allocation of rewards) and procedural justice (transparent, consistent processes for determining rewards). Simply ignoring the situation will likely worsen the problem.

questions.stem: An I/O psychology student is reviewing key concepts for the EPPP. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements about organizational and leadership theories:
questions.passage: (A) The Hawthorne Studies demonstrated that social and psychological factors significantly influence worker productivity, challenging purely economic models of motivation. (B) Fiedler's Contingency Model proposes that leaders should change their leadership style to match the situation. (C) Transformational leadership involves four components: idealized influence, inspirational motivation, intellectual stimulation, and individualized consideration. (D) Theory X managers assume workers are inherently lazy and must be closely supervised, while Theory Y managers assume workers are self-motivated and seek responsibility. (E) Path-Goal Theory proposes that the leader's primary function is to clarify paths to goals and remove obstacles for subordinates. (F) The Hawthorne effect refers to the tendency for participants to change behavior simply due to being studied. (G) Servant leadership theory proposes that leaders should prioritize their own advancement to maintain authority.
correctHighlights: (A) The Hawthorne Studies demonstrated that social and psychological factors significantly influence worker productivity, challenging purely economic models of motivation.
(C) Transformational leadership involves four components: idealized influence, inspirational motivation, intellectual stimulation, and individualized consideration.
(D) Theory X managers assume workers are inherently lazy and must be closely supervised, while Theory Y managers assume workers are self-motivated and seek responsibility.
(E) Path-Goal Theory proposes that the leader's primary function is to clarify paths to goals and remove obstacles for subordinates.
questions.explanation: Accurate statements: (A) The Hawthorne Studies (Mayo) revealed that attention, social dynamics, and worker attitudes influenced productivity more than physical conditions alone; (C) Bass's transformational leadership model includes the '4 I's'; (D) McGregor's Theory X and Theory Y describe contrasting managerial assumptions about human nature; (E) House's Path-Goal Theory focuses on how leaders facilitate goal attainment. Incorrect: (B) Fiedler argued leadership style is relatively fixed and the situation should be changed to fit the leader; (F) While often associated with the Hawthorne Studies, the 'Hawthorne effect' as described is a broader methodological concept about reactivity, and the original studies' findings were more nuanced; (G) Servant leadership (Greenleaf) prioritizes followers' needs and growth, not the leader's advancement.

questions.stem: A graduate student is reviewing training and development concepts. Highlight the THREE accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Kirkpatrick's four levels of training evaluation are reaction, learning, behavior, and results. (B) Transfer of training is enhanced when training conditions closely match the actual work environment (identical elements theory). (C) Needs analysis for training should be conducted at only one level: the task level. (D) Behavioral modeling training involves demonstrating desired behaviors, providing practice opportunities, and giving feedback. (E) On-the-job training is always superior to off-site training regardless of the skills being taught. (F) Overlearning during training can enhance retention and transfer by automating skills.
correctHighlights: (A) Kirkpatrick's four levels of training evaluation are reaction, learning, behavior, and results.
(B) Transfer of training is enhanced when training conditions closely match the actual work environment (identical elements theory).
(D) Behavioral modeling training involves demonstrating desired behaviors, providing practice opportunities, and giving feedback.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Kirkpatrick's widely-used model evaluates training at four levels—reaction (satisfaction), learning (knowledge/skill acquired), behavior (transfer to job), and results (organizational outcomes); (B) Thorndike's identical elements theory predicts better transfer when training and work environments share common elements (stimulus and response similarity); (D) Behavioral modeling (based on Bandura's social learning theory) uses modeling, rehearsal, and feedback—effective for interpersonal skills training. Incorrect: (C) Needs analysis should be conducted at three levels: organizational, task, and person analysis; (E) The optimal training method depends on the content, with off-site training sometimes preferred for complex or sensitive topics; (F) While overlearning can aid retention, the statement about automating skills oversimplifies—overlearning is most beneficial for procedural tasks.

questions.stem: Arrange Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs from the LOWEST (most basic) level to the HIGHEST level:

options.text: Self-actualization needs (fulfilling one's potential)
Safety and security needs
Esteem needs (achievement, recognition, status)
Physiological needs (food, water, shelter)
Belongingness and love needs (social relationships)

questions.explanation: Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs progresses from basic to higher-order: (1) Physiological needs—fundamental biological requirements for survival; (2) Safety needs—security, stability, protection from harm; (3) Belongingness and love needs—social connections, intimacy, acceptance; (4) Esteem needs—self-esteem, recognition, achievement, status; (5) Self-actualization—realizing one's full potential. Maslow proposed that lower needs must be substantially (not completely) satisfied before higher needs become primary motivators (prepotency). Alderfer's ERG Theory later simplified this to three levels and removed the rigid prepotency requirement, allowing frustration-regression.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps of a systematic training development process (ADDIE model) in the correct order:

options.text: Implementation—delivering the training program to participants
Design—specifying learning objectives, content, and methods
Evaluation—assessing training effectiveness using Kirkpatrick's levels
Analysis—conducting organizational, task, and person needs assessment
Development—creating training materials and pilot testing

questions.explanation: The ADDIE model represents the systematic instructional design process: (1) Analysis—identify training needs through organizational analysis (strategic goals), task analysis (job requirements), and person analysis (individual gaps); (2) Design—establish learning objectives, sequence content, select instructional methods; (3) Development—create materials, develop activities, conduct pilot testing; (4) Implementation—deliver the training program, manage logistics, support learners; (5) Evaluation—assess effectiveness at multiple levels (Kirkpatrick: reaction, learning, behavior, results). While presented linearly, the process is often iterative with feedback loops between stages.

questions.stem: Categorize each concept according to whether it belongs to Content theories of motivation, Process theories of motivation, or Job Design approaches:

items.text: Hackman and Oldham's Job Characteristics Model

questions.explanation: Content theories identify what motivates people (specific needs or factors): Maslow's Hierarchy (five need levels), Herzberg's Two-Factor (hygiene vs. motivators), and McClelland's Acquired Needs (achievement, affiliation, power). Process theories explain how motivation occurs (the psychological mechanisms): Vroom's Expectancy (effort-performance-outcome calculations), Adams' Equity (social comparison of input/outcome ratios), and Locke's Goal-Setting (specific, difficult goals direct and energize behavior). Job Design approaches focus on structuring work to enhance motivation: Hackman and Oldham's Job Characteristics Model (five core characteristics leading to critical psychological states) and strategies like job enlargement (horizontal expansion) and job rotation (lateral movement between tasks).

questions.stem: Categorize each leadership concept according to whether it represents a Trait approach, Behavioral approach, or Contingency/Situational approach:

items.text: Great Man theory—leaders are born with innate qualities
Ohio State studies—initiating structure and consideration dimensions
Fiedler's LPC model—matching leader style to situation
Big Five personality traits predicting leadership emergence
Blake and Mouton's Managerial Grid—concern for people vs. production
House's Path-Goal Theory—leader behavior matching subordinate needs

questions.explanation: Trait approaches assume leaders possess distinguishing personal characteristics: the Great Man theory (Carlyle) posited innate leadership qualities, and modern trait research examines Big Five personality traits (e.g., extraversion, conscientiousness, openness) as predictors of leadership emergence and effectiveness. Behavioral approaches focus on what leaders do: the Ohio State studies identified initiating structure and consideration; the Michigan studies distinguished employee-oriented and production-oriented behavior; Blake and Mouton's Grid mapped concern for people vs. production. Contingency/Situational approaches argue effectiveness depends on the match between leader behavior and situational factors: Fiedler's LPC model, Hersey-Blanchard's readiness-based model, and House's Path-Goal Theory all specify conditions under which different leadership behaviors are most effective.

questions.stem: Examine the following organizational data trends collected from a large corporation during a period that includes a major disruption (pandemic onset in 2020). Based on the data, what conclusion is BEST supported?
options: Remote work had no measurable impact on job satisfaction or organizational outcomes
The sharp increase in remote work coincided with decreased satisfaction, commitment, and increased turnover intentions, with gradual recovery as organizations adapted
Turnover intentions decreased steadily throughout the entire period
Organizational commitment is unrelated to job satisfaction
questions.explanation: The data show clear patterns: the 2020 disruption (pandemic) forced rapid remote work adoption (12% to 78%), coinciding with sharp declines in job satisfaction (7.0 to 5.8) and organizational commitment (7.3 to 5.5), and a spike in turnover intentions (18% to 35%). As organizations adapted and remote work partially normalized (declining from 78% to 45%), satisfaction, commitment, and turnover intentions gradually improved but had not fully returned to pre-disruption levels by 2022. This illustrates Lewin's change model: the forced unfreezing disrupted equilibrium; the moving phase involved adaptation; and partial refreezing occurred as new norms developed. It also demonstrates the interrelationship between job satisfaction, organizational commitment, and turnover intention consistent with I/O research.

values.label: Team A: Specific difficult goals + feedback
Team B: 'Do your best' goals + feedback
Team C: Specific difficult goals, no feedback
Team D: No goals, no feedback (control)

questions.stem: An organization implemented different goal-setting conditions across four teams and tracked performance scores over five quarters. Review the data and select the conclusion BEST supported by the results:
options: Feedback alone is sufficient to produce sustained performance improvement
Specific, difficult goals combined with feedback produce the greatest and most sustained performance gains, consistent with Locke and Latham's theory
'Do your best' goals are equally effective as specific difficult goals when feedback is provided
Goal-setting has no meaningful effect on performance
questions.explanation: The data strongly support Locke and Latham's Goal-Setting Theory. Team A (specific difficult goals + feedback) shows continuous improvement from 62 to 85—the largest and most sustained gain. Team B ('do your best' + feedback) shows minimal improvement, demonstrating that vague goals are ineffective even with feedback. Team C (specific goals without feedback) shows initial improvement that plateaus and declines, illustrating that goals without feedback are insufficient for sustained improvement (people cannot adjust effort without progress information). Team D (control) shows no change. This pattern perfectly illustrates the theory's core propositions: specific, difficult goals outperform vague goals, and feedback is a necessary moderator of the goal-performance relationship.
